column4: Hi all.  I had (yet another) question. My wife and I are about to reformat her old Windows Xp partition. (woo hoo!)  I am uncertain as to the location of GRUB though, and don't want to leave her computer unbootable.

if your bios was made within the last 10 years, grub should properly write over the MBR and display a menu on boot for what OS to run.  You can rezise NTFS partitions, btw, so you could install both OSs at the same time
Nice. Well, we're actually just getting rid of her Win Xp partition for the space. She's decided to go Ubuntu 100%.
have you used linux much before?
For the last several months, yes.
How to install GRUB if erasing the old win partition destroys it.

First partition on the disk is primary, contains the old Win XP install.  The rest of the disk is an extended partition that includes the various partitions Ubuntu is using.  swap, /, /home/, and a FAT32 shared part.
okay.  So you're going to delete the windows partition, and then what?
Format it.  reiserfs or maybe ext3.  Space for the wife's files.  The /home partition is getting cramped. ;)
when you type `mount` does it list it?
and reka:  Here's my plan. Format the partition and reinstall GRUB from the rescue terminal of the install CD, then copy over the existing grub menu to the new boot partition.  Good idea? Bad?
any reason you need a boot partition now, but didn't before?
There's a boot partition. It's just housed in the Windows partition we're going to destroy.
So the short answer to your question is that there was a boot partition before. lol
then why do you need to change anything?  lol sorry I'm not being very helpful..
Because the existing boot partition is about to be eradicated when we format that part of the drive, and my wife needs a bootable computer.  lmao.

Okay. I just checked out her GRUB menu.lst. The Grub root is referring to (hd0,1) Which is the second partition on her first hard drive. That's her current Ubuntu /, meanign that I'm nto going to be wiping out any kernels here.  Thanks for the help!
